data.text:
BATTLE OF MANILA

 The Battle of Manila (4–5 February 1899) was the largest and first battle of the Philippine-American War, which lasted from 1899 to 1902. It was an insurgency that may be considered as a continuation of the Philippine Revolution against Spanish control. Filipino expectations that the United States' defeat of their Spanish colonial masters in the Spanish-American War of 1898 would lead to the Philippines' independence were crushed when the US acquired the islands for its own use. The conflict began in Manila with a brief but violent confrontation between Filipino independence militants and US troops.

THE UGLY ORIGINS OF AMERICA’S ENVOVLVEMENT IN THE

PHILIPPINES

 Filipinos believed three centuries of colonialism were finished after America conquered Spain in 1898. Under the leadership of Emilio Aguinaldo, they declared the birth of a republic, drafted a constitution, and established a government. However, under the provisions of the Treaty of Paris, which concluded the war, America paid Spain $20 million for the roughly 7,600 islands that make up the Philippines.

DURING WW-II AND THE END OF THE WAR

 Ex-US Army M5 Stuart light tanks of the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) after independence. Already obsolete in the tank vs tank role, these served into the 1950s.

 In late 1941 and early 1942, Japanese forces overran the Philippines, which was then an American Commonwealth. Guerrillas fought back against the IJA's 14th Area Army during the occupation. After WWII, some of the guerillas were absorbed into the Philippine military. Prior to WWII, the US had set a deadline of mid-1945 for the Philippines to gain independence. Throughout WWII, it was often declared that this would be honored, and the Philippines did so on July 4, 1946, only a few months after the 1930s plan and less than a year after WWII ended.

M3 SUBMACHINE GUN

 The M3 SpecOps Generation 2, also known as the M Gen2 or PN/PMC M3, is a modernized version of the M3 grease gun constructed from pre-existing caches of the 1940s-era weapon. The weapon, which is primarily used for ship seizures and boarding operations, is the Philippine navy's method of teaching an old dog new tricks.

BOLO KNIFE

 Throughout the Philippine Revolution, the Katipunan employed the Bolo knife as their primary weapon. It was also used by Filipino guerrillas and bolomen during the Philippine– American War. The Katipunan and the Philippine Revolution, notably the Cry of Pugad Lawin, are represented by the bolo. Andres Bonifacio, like other important Katipuneros, is shown wielding a bolo in one hand and the Katipunan flag in the other on several monuments.

LANTAKA

 Filipino soldiers occasionally utilized makeshift artillery guns consisting of water pipes reinforced with bamboo or wood that could only fire once or twice.

BATTLE OF MANILA BAY

 The United States defeated the Spanish Pacific fleet at the Battle of Manila Bay on May 1, 1898. The loss of the Philippines as a result of the Navy's actions contributed to the United States' eventual triumph in the Spanish-American War. Commodore George Dewey became a national hero as a result of the stunning American victory, which helped establish the US as a strong naval force.

Remington Rolling Block rifle

 Remington Rolling Block is a family of breech- loading rifles that was produced from the mid- 1860s into the early 20th century by E. Remington and Sons (later Remington Arms Company). The action was extremely strong, and could easily withstand the increased pressure of the new smokeless powders coming into use by the late 1880s a Rifle issued to Tiradores (Sharpshooters).
